reviews.text: The Dark Knight takes comic book characters and plants them firmly in the real world. Revealing a Gotham defined by human flaws and plummeting into freefall. That realism puts it head and shoulders above almost anything else and redefines a genre.
reviews.author: Martin Carr

reviews.text: With a memorable performance from Heath Ledger, masterful direction from Nolan, and bold storytelling, this film stands out as one of the best comic book adaptations in film history. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juan Pablo Russo

reviews.text: It doesn’t matter how many superhero movies its crosstown rival makes; it’ll never match the brilliance that Nolan delivered the same year Marvel began its infinite project. Firing on all cylinders … this is the most complete film Nolan has ever made.
reviews.author: Akhil Arora

reviews.text: For the longest time, I’ve viewed this film as the Godfather of live-action Batman films.
reviews.author: Christian Eulinberg

reviews.text: The pinnacle of Nolan’s career so far, The Dark Knight is one of the most impressionable films of the 21st century (and one of the best).
reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.text: An incomparable crime thriller and superhero film, and an instant classic in both genres
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: A masterpiece within or outside the superhero & comic book genre it explores. Heath Ledger delivers one of the most iconic performances in film history. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: A rare beast. It's a summer blockbuster with equal parts brain and brawn.
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: The famous masked vigilante has never looked or felt more intense.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: With his smeared whiteface make-up and leering razor-slashed smile, Ledger's Joker is creepy enough to look at, but what he represents is even more chilling.
reviews.author: Jason Best

reviews.text: The awards hype is warranted.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: The Dark Knight managed to capture something complex and instinctive about the "war on terror" era.
reviews.author: Siddhant Adlakha

reviews.text: A masterpiece. Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight is not only one of the greatest comic book movies you'll ever see, but also one of the best films of all-time.
reviews.author: Josh Wilding

reviews.text: It seems almost cruel to take beloved child archetypes and turn them into projections for adult angst.
reviews.author: Felicia Feaster

reviews.text: Heath Ledger gives one of the best performances of the last twenty years. When you watch his take on the Joker, it's one of complete surprise and mystery. It's frightening with how chaotic and mischievous he makes him.
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: Ledger's performance alone is good enough to make The Dark Knight a very good movie, but fortunately this is a film with even more than that -- making it the not just the best film of the summer, but one of the best films of the year.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: The Dark Knight represents a masterpiece in filmmaking as Christopher Nolan takes the Batman Begins sequel to an entirely new level.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: The definitive movie of its genre and the best Batman film to date
reviews.author: Mattie Lucas

reviews.text: Heath Ledger is great.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: The movie's a real neo-noir all right, wallowing in darkness, thrilled with how bad we are, and getting such a kick out of our impending doom it cheers you right up.
reviews.author: Eileen Jones

reviews.text: Not just a perfect comic book movie, not just a perfect Batman movie, but darn-near a perfect movie, full stop.
reviews.author: Zaki Hasan

reviews.text: A film is only as good as its villain. By that standard, The Dark Knight achieves true greatness.
reviews.author: Marcianne Miller

reviews.text: The Dark Knight always ought to be played on the biggest screen possible, and played loud, like a Led Zepplin song. Director Christopher Nolans' skyscapes, the helicopter shots and views from the 200th floor, are IMAX at its best.
reviews.author: Richard von Busack

reviews.text: It might not be the most fun superhero movie ever made, but it's certainly the most mature, complex and intriguing of them all. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: The Dark Knight may not supply a happy ending, but there is a feeling of exhilaration as Batman rides off from the pursuing cops, and the realization that this is another big step forward for comic book movies.
reviews.author: Matthew Goudreau

reviews.text: The action sequences are like being injected with a shot of adrenalin straight into the heart.
reviews.author: Kaleem Aftab

reviews.text: This may seem like faint praise, but about the highest compliment I can give Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight right now is to say that there were many long stretches during which I didn't even realize it was a superhero movie
reviews.author: Glenn Kenny

reviews.text: Too much psychology and not enough pop. It's possible to be too serious, you know.
reviews.author: Ryan Gilbey

reviews.text: Pretty deep stuff from a popcorn picture, and it's one reason why the movie theaters right now are such a rich vein of entertainment.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: One of the most stylish extravaganzas in years.
reviews.author: Rashid Irani

reviews.text: As summer movies go, The Dark Knight is head and shoulders above most.
reviews.author: Paul Wells

reviews.text: You will feel utterly numb after the screening of The Dark Knight. The film is bleak and brilliant.
reviews.author: James Christopher

reviews.text: The weight of expectation should have crushed this movie.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: Nolan has squeezed enough material for a saga into two and a half hours. The action moves insanely fast, the exposition is breathless, and the big setpieces practically tread on each other's heels. Down time doesn't exist in this film.
reviews.author: Margot Harrison

reviews.text: Declaring Christopher Nolan's Batman movie to be the best-ever comic book adaptation or one of the top action flicks of all time understates what he accomplishes.
reviews.author: Steve Persall

reviews.text: This is an impressive film in many ways, and Nolan directs with real confidence, yet the overall result feels cumbersome.
reviews.author: Jonathan Romney

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a clever, loud, technically brilliant film, superbly designed by Nathan Crowley and dramatically lit by Wally Pfister. Whether such a movie can bear the increasing moral weight imposed upon it is another matter.
reviews.author: Philip French

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a triumph from beginning to end.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: The phenomenal The Dark Knight now reigns as the greatest superhero film of all time. From its exhilarating first frame to its bittersweet last, it sets a new standard for the genre -- and redefines what a summer popcorn movie can be.
reviews.author: Jason Lynch

reviews.text: Among the great strengths of The Dark Knight is the way it combines hardboiled naturalism with the kind of stunts and setpieces you expect in summer blockbusters.
reviews.author: Geoffrey Macnab

reviews.text: Brilliantly bleak and chillingly Gothic (credit the enthralling cinematography by Wally Pfister), The Dark Knight emerges as the first truly great film of 2008.
reviews.author: Nate Deen

reviews.text: The most thematically sophisticated, most philosophically profound, most narratively complex and most viscerally thrilling super-hero movie of all. It transcends the genre.
reviews.author: Mike Davies

reviews.text: The Dark Knight takes the process a giant leap further, transforming a typical summer blockbuster into a brooding, unsettling reflection on the increasingly blurry boundaries between good and evil.
reviews.author: Allan Hunter

reviews.text: Does it match the hype? Yes.
reviews.author: AskMen.com Staff

reviews.text: At two and a half hours, it's a little exhausting, but I honestly can't say what I'd cut.
reviews.author: Norman Wilner

reviews.text: Dark, mysterious and pulsating almost from start to finish, Batman's return to the big screen has set a new benchmark for the superhero film, leaving the plethora of recent comic book capers firmly in its wake.
reviews.author: Andrew Welsh

reviews.text: It's too long and Nolan tosses in too many twists near the end. But it delivers ongoing adrenalin rushes, mental popcorn to chew over and a rich atmosphere to get lost in. And it's impressive enough to rank as summer's strongest blockbuster.
reviews.author: Barry Caine

reviews.text: Most of the film is entertaining. The cast is uniformly excellent and the resounding praise aimed at the late Heath Ledger is deserved.
reviews.author: Alex Fitch

reviews.text: Christopher Nolan's rich and engrossing adventure rip-roars across the cinema screen, bullying blockbusters into new territory.
reviews.author: Andrew Hedley

reviews.text: To talk of Heath Ledger's performance is difficult, merely because, as gigantic as it is, it is only one important feature of an intricately wrought canvas.
reviews.author: Tiru Thiruvilangam

reviews.text: If Batman Begins was the classy hors d'oeuvre in Christopher Nolan's blockbuster trilogy, then this awesome follow-up is a main course that delivers on all levels.
reviews.author: Jeremy Aspinall

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a rarity in Hollywood -- a truly earnest adaptation that in many ways exceeds even the brilliance of the work upon which it is based.
reviews.author: Neil Miller

reviews.text: Nolan's Dark Knight constantly keeps us off-balance and fills us with breathless anticipation for the next stunning turn-of-events. Ask yourself this: How long has it been since you've seen a movie like that?
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is probably the smartest and most stylish action movie since the "The Matrix." It thinks and philosophizes. The subject it thinks and philosophizes about, perhaps not surprisingly, considering the times, is the Iraq war.
reviews.author: Timothy Mangan

reviews.text: What you finally receive from The Dark Knight, then, isn't a message but a sensation, which comes from the deliberately twisted form. You learn how it feels to be in a vortex that just keeps sucking you down.
reviews.author: Stuart Klawans

reviews.text: Once firmly established, the bludgeoning pace of one Joker rampage after another pounds the film's carefully detailed collaboration into mush.
reviews.author: Michael Joshua Rowin

reviews.text: [The Dark Knight] is the right movie at the right time, especially if you have a burning desire to be excited and depressed simultaneously.
reviews.author: Jay Stone

reviews.text: Sometimes it's easy to overlook the message in a film and just enjoy the action, but not here, as Nolan, Bale, Ledger, Eckhart, and compatriots take viewers on a compelling journey through moral ambiguity and the masks we all wear.
reviews.author: Nanciann Cherry

reviews.text: An exceptionally smart, brooding picture with some terrific performances.
reviews.author: Tom Charity

reviews.text: Were films judged entirely by the emotive impact of their opening and closing images, The Dark Knight would be a masterpiece.
reviews.author: Rob Humanick

reviews.text: The glimpse into the Joker's darkness during his documented torture scene is a credit to the devastatingly lost potential of Heath Ledger.
reviews.author: Blake Howard

reviews.text: It's not just the best Batman film ever. It's not just the best superhero movie ever. It's more than a money-spinner, a franchise, a comic-book cash-in. The Dark Knight is a stunning piece of work that deserves every word of praise spoken about it.
reviews.author: Ali Gray

reviews.text: A phenomenal masterpiece whose creators aren't content with simply making a great comic book movie, but craft one that transcends the genre to become one of the best films this decade.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: Thank Warner Bros. for letting Nolan make such a smart, thrilling, emotionally involving, just terrifically well rounded and fully realized entertainment that challenges and elevates notions of what a so-called 'summer blockbuster' can do.
reviews.author: Michael Dequina

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is the best kind of sequel -- one that uses its predecessor as a gateway to explore new facets of its characters and its world.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: Visceral and terrifying.
reviews.author: Michael W. Phillips, Jr.

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a film that's fantastic on the action front, seeds its acrobatics in its own reality, and always feels relevant even when its ideas are drowned out by clatter.
reviews.author: Dave Calhoun

reviews.text: Even if this wasn't Ledger's final role before his untimely death last year, his Joker would still go down in cinema history as one of the most creepily unhinged big-screen bad guys of all time.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: More than a comic-book adventure, this is a sprawling crime epic.
reviews.author: Stella Papamichael

reviews.text: You know you're watching a good movie when it puts a smile on your face right from the start. In the The Dark Knight it may be a twisted grimace but given the right perspective there's enjoyment to be had in even the bleakest subject matter.
reviews.author: Joshua Starnes

reviews.text: Excellent sequel much darker, more violent than the first.
reviews.author: James Rocchi

reviews.text: Allusions to our current struggles with surveillance, public perception and terrorism are thrown into the mix, adding political immediacy to Nolan's psycho noir.
reviews.author: Jeff Meyers

reviews.text: Bring on part three.
reviews.author: Coco Forsythe

reviews.text: With his sliced visage, enough knives to supply a steak-house chain, and makeup that makes Courtney Love's bad days look pretty, this Joker is the picture of pure evil.
reviews.author: Patty Jones

reviews.text: Completely lacking in vanity, Ledger creates his finest performance.
reviews.author: Brett Michel

reviews.text: Christopher Nolan is much, much smarter than your average filmmaker.
reviews.author: Laremy Legel

reviews.text: Flawed and overrated.
reviews.author: Adam Nayman

reviews.text: In this one, Gotham is finally a real city.
reviews.author: Scott Nash

reviews.text: It not only surpasses Batman Begins - previously considered the high-water mark of movies about the Caped Crusader - but one that magnificently transcends the superhero genre.
reviews.author: Mike Scott

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a masterpiece of the first order, and the first great post-Sept. 11 film.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: Middling as a summer blockbuster, zero as art, and more than a bit alarming as a phenomenon

reviews.text: Despite its superhero trappings, The Dark Knight is more a piece of film noir.
reviews.author: Steve Biodrowski

reviews.text: Can one great character carry an entire movie? ....the answer is obviously yes. Ledger does it.
reviews.author: John J. Puccio

reviews.text: The symbiosis of good and evil is the film's philosophical core, and images of duality and cloaked identity are strewn through it like shards from a fun house mirror.

reviews.text: There is enough psychology thrown around to keep film classes in business for years.
reviews.author: Marie Asner

reviews.text: For all the Oscar buzz surrounding Heath Ledger in the past few weeks, there still aren't enough hours in the day to gush about his knockout performance as The Joker.
reviews.author: Jason Zingale

reviews.text: Lacks a sense of humor and a notion about the essential silliness of this premise.
reviews.author: Jean Lowerison

reviews.text: An amazing piece of filmmaking that rockets the Batman legacy to heights never imagined, fueled by Heath Ledger's amazing re-invention of The Joker.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: In The Dark Knight, when mortals tangle in the affairs of the gods, they get burned.
reviews.author: Chris Barsanti

reviews.text: The Dark Knight delivered on many fronts.
reviews.author: JoBlo

reviews.text: a riveting piece of work that will have us all mourning Ledger's loss but smacking our lips for a third entry
reviews.author: Mike Sage

reviews.text: [Ledger gives] a bravura performance full of madness and menace, one that makes this clown truly frightening.

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is the best Batman film ever made, the best superhero movie ever made, and the best movie of the year to date.
reviews.author: Caffeinated Clint

reviews.text: This is without a doubt the best -- and most important -- picture of the year.
reviews.author: David Keyes

reviews.text: The Dark Knight has raised the bar for the comic book superhero genre - it's a Batman movie for grown-ups.
reviews.author: Vic Holtreman

reviews.text: A big summer blockbuster dripping in characters.
reviews.author: Emily Blunt

reviews.text: This film is sure to surpass your wildest expectations. The summer film that is sure to be unforgettable and leave you craving for more.
reviews.author: Jolene Mendez

reviews.text: ...even if Ledger hadn't died, critics and audiences alike would still be buzzing about the star's turn as The Joker.
reviews.author: Paul Salfen

reviews.text: ...we can have not just good comic book movies, but amazing comic book movies.
reviews.author: Widgett Walls

reviews.text: relatively high-quality pulp.
reviews.author: Christopher Null

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is neither a good nor a serious film. It is ill-conceived and poorly done, overlong, confusing and emotionally muddy.
reviews.author: David Walsh

reviews.text: Powerful acting, powerful action, huge IMAX sequences give this Batman a great big commanding feel. However, story is held hostage to action, especially in the second half.
reviews.author: Ross Anthony

reviews.text: Nolan gives in a bit to bloated-sequel syndrome ... but this is still one of the most riveting, trilling and wrenching movies of the year.

reviews.text: It could be the bleakest big-budget adventure since Blade Runner tanked on release near the dawn of the Reagan era.
reviews.author: Bryant Frazer

reviews.text: ... director Christopher Nolan's much-hyped, long awaited second entry in the Batman franchise is not only fabulous and the best film of the summer, it's possibly the best film of the year, a guaranteed mammoth hit.
reviews.author: Sura Wood

reviews.text: "So here it is: The best superhero movie ever. The Dark Knight deftly accomplishes all one could hope for, and then it surpasses it, and then it continues to surprise. The movie isn't just a triumph, it is that rare pop-culture oddity: A masterpiece."
reviews.author: Christopher Smith

reviews.text: ...many excellent moments and action set-pieces...
reviews.author: Jim Lane

reviews.text: Be not fooled, this movie may circle D.A. Harvey Dent, and may toy with Wayne's weariness and loneliness, but this story belongs heart and soul to Ledger's Joker.

reviews.text: [Ledger's] manic zest gives the film its energy.
reviews.author: Nick Curtis

reviews.text: You will exit the cinema with an enhanced respect for Nolan's intelligence, for Wally Pfister's pin-sharp cinematography, and, sadly, for an acting talent tragically curtailed.

reviews.text: The plot is often impossible to follow. And the film, though dark, isn't as deep as some have claimed.
reviews.author: Christopher Tookey

reviews.text: An obvious improvement over its immediate predecessor...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: The first five-star blockbuster of the year has arrived, and in style.
reviews.author: Rob Daniel

reviews.text: Shouldn't Nolan, marvellous as his directing here is, be creating original films rather than rebooting and retooling franchise fare?
reviews.author: Sukhdev Sandhu

reviews.text: Watching the first dizzying, vertiginous overhead shot of the glittering skyscrapers and minuscule streets, I literally forgot to breathe for a second or two, and found myself teetering forward on my seat...
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: ...a movie that fulfills the promise of the best Hollywood movies in that it offers us transport to an alternate yet recognizable reality.
reviews.author: Philip Martin

reviews.text: Believe the hype. The Dark Knight is, quite simply, the superhero of superhero films.
reviews.author: Bruce Bennett

reviews.text: Lo mejor, por lejos: la descollante actuación póstuma de Heath Ledger como el Guasón definitivo. Quizás el primer blockbuster de culto del siglo XXI.

reviews.text: Everything you've heard is true...brilliant.
reviews.author: John Venable

reviews.text: Hugely entertaining, superbly acted and stunningly designed blockbuster that mixes adult themes with spectacular action and actually leaves you wanting more, despite its lengthy running time.
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: thanks to an atypically meaty screenplay, this might very well be the best superhero movie of all time, and is the only film in this genre that is so well crafted that it deserves some serious respect when Oscar season rolls around next year.
reviews.author: Sean McBride

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is both a brilliantly nihilistic, incredibly dark and richly layered filmgoing experience, and a painful reminder of what the film world lost with the senseless death of Heath Ledger.
reviews.author: Lori Hoffman

reviews.text: It manages to bring together an action film and a thought piece. This is a lot more than we have come to expect from a comic book film.
reviews.author: Mark R. Leeper

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is so thrillingly-executed, primeval and exhilarating, it will forever sear itself into your consciousness. It might also be the most intelligent blockbuster movie ever made.
reviews.author: Orlando Parfitt

reviews.text: Batman and Robin it ain't; it's hard to believe "The Dark Knight" and Joel Schumacher's infamous camp extravaganza even came from the same universe, let alone the same franchise.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: A must-see for Ledger alone, but there's more to it than that. If anything, the film is a grim portrait of our own paranoia, sense of hopelessness and selfishness.
reviews.author: Ken Hanke

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a film steeped in tragedy, sacrifice, and heroism, and the eternal struggle at its core gives it a resonance that makes it one for the ages.
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: The action is devastating, high-wire and realistic.
reviews.author: Matthew De Abaitua

reviews.text: The darkest and most clever of all of the superhero movies ever made.
reviews.author: Wesley Lovell

reviews.text: Nolan and company did such an incredible job with this and tied up all the loose ends so well, that it's hard to fathom what they could do and where they could go with a 3rd film. I sincerely hope there isn't another Batman film. You can't top perfection.
reviews.author: Michelle Alexandria

reviews.text: Scripted by Nolan and his brother Jonathan, The Dark Knight is laced with the depths of thematic aspiration that can catapult a summer tentpole into the realms of the mythic.
reviews.author: James Kendrick

reviews.text: A sinister epic that manages to turn its pulp, comic book source into complex and thrilling art for the masses.
reviews.author: Richard Knight

reviews.text: Batman started out as a comic that grew gothic that has turned psychotic. The Dark Knight is one long movie about madness.
reviews.author: Victor Olliver

reviews.text: Besides a couple of flaws and Batman's distractingly garbled voice, this is one entertaining superhero crime saga.
reviews.author: Austin Kennedy

reviews.text: 'The Dark Knight' boasts a visual splendor that matches its trenchant themes and inspired performances.
reviews.author: John P. McCarthy

reviews.text: A stupendous performance by the late Heath Ledger burns this incarnation of The Joker into our psyche as securely as did Jack Nicholson's. But even more than Nicholson, Ledger plays The Joker for real..
reviews.author: Andrew L. Urban

reviews.text: Good, but overrated.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: The hardware is played down this time and the result is character intensive movie that just so happens to have some of the best special effects of the season.
reviews.author: Robin Clifford

reviews.text: At one point, all of Gotham believes that Aaron Eckhart is Batman. Indie-man, maybe. Or Blonde with Split Chin-man. But I'd sooner believe that Val Kilmer is Batman. And what are the odds of that?
reviews.author: Mark Ramsey

reviews.text: It plays with the same themes as a lot of other superhero movies, but is about something bigger.
reviews.author: Eric Melin

reviews.text: It is a supreme achievement in its genre. It doesn't transcend its comic book origins, but rather faithfully represents them, wholly unembarrassed to deliver its story on its own terms.
reviews.author: Jeremy Heilman

reviews.text: Batman lives to absorb blame in order to save the worthy, and soldier (or speedbike) on.
reviews.author: Jules Brenner

reviews.text: Impeccably acted, morally complex and crafted with across-the-board technical virtuosity...emerges fully formed as an American crime-movie classic.
reviews.author: Geoff Berkshire

reviews.text: Without question one of the most demonic, pure incarnations of nightmarish instant classic movie villains, Heath Ledger's Joker self-mutilated danger junkie, misery loves company chaos freak in hellish warpaint may be gone, but will never be forgotten.

reviews.text: Heath Ledger's performance was a strong contributor, but Christopher Nolan's writing and direction is the real star.
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: You heard it here first: the late Heath Ledger will win an Academy Award for his defining, spine-tingling performance as The Joker.

reviews.text: ...in the world of movies based on comic book heroes, there are the new Batman films, and then there's everything else.

reviews.text: Not just a comic book movie but a virtual dissertation on the nature of good and evil, as well as the thin line that sometimes separates them.

reviews.text: A near flawless example of superhero cinema with marvelous performances, a top notch script, and direction that aims for a more adult audience...

reviews.text: No wonder people were lined up long before midnight for the first showing.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: Everything you would want to see in a movie... I wanted to applaud after every scene Heath Ledger performed... features Batman's most wonderful toys yet.

reviews.text: Now you see it, now you don't.

reviews.text: With only three short words comprising the film's enigmatic title, it also boasts three epic claims to fame: the role of a lifetime for the late Heath Ledger, one of the best films of 2008 and one of the greatest superhero films of all time.
reviews.author: Adam Fendelman

reviews.text: Far from offering traditional summer escapism...a brainy, action-packed morality play meant to throttle the audience, body and mind, for a solid 152 minutes and haunt them for days and weeks later.
reviews.author: Wade Major

reviews.text: The Dark Knight might be the first superhero movie that exudes a palpable sense of dread and menace that tugs at our nerves in a way that both disturbs and delights us.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Christopher Nolan's latest exploration of the Batman mythology steeps its muddled plot in so much murk that the Joker's maniacal nihilism comes to seem like a recurrent grace note.
reviews.author: Joe Morgenstern

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is even more blazingly ambitious than its predecessor, the 2005 Batman Begins.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: The film is so relentlessly bleak that, paradoxically, its blackness is not given its full due. But this comic-book movie is more disturbing, and has more freakish power, than anything else I've seen all year.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: During the summer of 2008, at least, the price of a single movie ticket isn't likely to buy more on-screen entertainment value and cinematic ambition than The Dark Knight.
reviews.author: John Wirt

reviews.text: Believe every ounce of the hype surrounding The Dark Knight.
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: Nolan hasn't just created another comic book film, but a well crafted solid engrossing thriller
reviews.author: Wilson Morales

reviews.text: Nolan and Co. do weave an enormous and gratifyingly textured tapestry of plot, giving unexpectedly affecting moments to characters we initially see as mere background figures.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: A drama about hard moral choices, 'The Dark Knight' is 'The Godfather' of superhero movies -- or, at least, 'The Departed.'
reviews.author: John Beifuss

reviews.text: Quite good. Nolan's visually sophisticated and well-acted sequel engages and even wows for about two hours of its 2 1/2 -hour run time.
reviews.author: Carla Meyer

reviews.text: Ambitious and relentlessly dark and altogether better than its predecessor.
reviews.author: Glenn Whipp

reviews.text: Watching The Dark Knight is like gazing into a mirror on a waning moon night: chilling and mesmerizing.
reviews.author: Lisa Kennedy

reviews.text: Ledger makes the Joker his, imbuing the character with such menace and genuine insanity I finally got a sense of what talent he really had.
reviews.author: Pete Vonder Haar

reviews.text: Like a symphony where every note is exactly where it needs to be, or a painting without a brushstroke wasted, The Dark Knight is an unabashed, unashamedly great film.
reviews.author: Bill Gibron

reviews.text: Delves so deeply into the darkness that lurks in the hearts of men that it comes almost as a shock, bordering on euphoria, to find that it maintains a tenacious grip onto hope in the human potential for good.
reviews.author: Steven D. Greydanus

reviews.text: If a movie is only as good as its villain, then Dark Knight is a winner, hands down.
reviews.author: Barbara Vancheri

reviews.text: Puts Nolan in the same league as Brian de Palma, Martin Scorsese and Michael Mann.
reviews.author: Scott A. Mantz

reviews.text: The stunts are exciting, but here's an action movie where the bits in between feel like more than setup for the next set piece. We've seen Bat movies that wink, sink or stink; this one thinks.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: Supremely satisfying for about a dozen different reasons. A great film.
reviews.author: Scott Weinberg

reviews.text: Someone get the Batman a lozenge.
reviews.author: Devin Faraci

reviews.text: Christian Bale is magnificent as the tortured hero, but the movie belongs to its freaky villain.
reviews.author: Pauline Adamek

reviews.text: Despite the tensions between its form and its function, The Dark Knight succeeds far more than it fails, and lingers provocatively in the mind.
reviews.author: Christopher Orr

reviews.text: Oh, and if skin-crawling performances, complex storytelling, and profound ideas don't do it for you...did I mention that the film is completely badass?
reviews.author: Marc Fennell

reviews.text: This is a terrific movie, the action sequences are splendiferous, the acting impeccable but there's something missing at the heart of it. And it seems to be Batman.
reviews.author: Margaret Pomeranz

reviews.text: Heath Ledger's Joker is, in many ways, symbolic of Nolan's overall success with The Dark Knight; subtle and restrained, but always two shakes shy of bloody holocaust and a masterpiece of cinema that time will verify.
reviews.author: Patrick Kolan

reviews.text: The Dark Knight illuminates courtesy of Ledger's brilliant interpretation of the madman.
reviews.author: Des Partridge

reviews.text: Ledger is magnificently malevolent. He creates a character who revels in mayhem, a criminal with no agenda other than to spread terror.
reviews.author: Bob Bloom

reviews.text: A triumph in comic book movies...the best Batman movie ever made. But it is Ledger's demeanor--his body language, eye contact, and delivery--that gets under one's skin.
reviews.author: Steve Crum

reviews.text: At the core of what is undoubtedly the most intense, and even at times horrific, superhero movie yet made is Ledger's extraordinary performance.
reviews.author: David Stratton

reviews.text: There is an exquisite order in the chaos, a fascist formality and video game surrealism that resists the forces of disintegration with a sort of superhuman determination.
reviews.author: Ruth Hessey

reviews.text: While the film may be a hell of a ride, it takes a hell of a long time for the ride to grind its way out of first gear.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: As promised, Heath Ledger is terrifying. Cruelty plus cleverness is a fearsome combination.
reviews.author: Sandra Hall

reviews.text: Nolan is clearly on the title character's wavelength and understands how a crisis of such magnitude might affect good men trying to do the right thing.
reviews.author: Rob Vaux

reviews.text: The late Heath Ledger will be missed because of his ability to make a green-haired clown into the most terrifying sight in recent memory.
reviews.author: Dan Lybarger

reviews.text: [Gotham City] stands in for any of today's civilized nations and becomes ripe for thematic exploration. And Nolan wastes no chance to utilize this world for a tale about how fragile our morality is.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Chen

reviews.text: Batman becomes a supporting player to the characters of Dent and the Joker
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: Mixed with the flashes of absolute brilliance are long dead sections. The film left me more often bored than entertained. It's a certain candidate for my list of this year's most overrated movies.
reviews.author: Steve Rhodes

reviews.text: The Joker's scenes reveal a lean, mean thriller hidden inside a bloated superhero epic.
reviews.author: David Cornelius

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a complex and violent tale of clashing egos. The disturbed verses the disturbing. And in the title, underline the word dark. Add an asterisk. Italicize dark's font. Make it bold and bigger.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: Director Christopher Nolan has crafted a Batman film of such devastating impact, it practically obliterates the memory of its predecessors -- including Nolan's own Batman Begins.
reviews.author: Alex Markerson

reviews.text: Pitched at the divide between art and industry, poetry and entertainment, The Dark Knight goes darker and deeper than any Hollywood movie of its comic-book kind.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: It's the new gold standard for superhero noir.
reviews.author: Sean Axmaker

reviews.text: Tremendous fun.
reviews.author: Shawn Levy

reviews.text: This is the kind of movie going experience that people tell their grand kids about.
reviews.author: Bill Clark

reviews.text: Ledger's manically endearing performance as the unhinged psycho giving both cops and crooks nightmares is so riveting that it makes you sad for all the roles he'll never have a chance to tackle.
reviews.author: Beth Accomando

reviews.text: Heath Ledger's bravura performance will glitter for as long as movies exist.
reviews.author: Tony Medley

reviews.text: ...if, like me, you've always thought the Paul Dini/Bruce Timm animated version was tops, you should be pretty happy with what Christopher Nolan has done this time around.
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: An explosively provocative [film]. ... Exhilaratingly straightforward action sequences matched by moral complexity of a sort not usually associated with comic-book movie franchises.
reviews.author: Bob Mondello

reviews.text: The whole thing would be worthwhile if for nothing else than the late Ledger's brilliant and creepy performance as the unhinged, deranged villain. Hopefully, his achievement will be remembered when film-award season comes around.
reviews.author: Jeff Vice

reviews.text: Ambitious, flawed and erratically visionary, Batman is back.
reviews.author: Jeanne Aufmuth

reviews.text: It's a movie about America, terrorism and the rule of law; about heroism and human nature. The dude in the bat suit is just window-dressing.
reviews.author: Eugene Novikov

reviews.text: Quite simply, when you see The Dark Knight, you're going to realize how truly awful the first wave of Batman films were.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: Where Batman Begins was largely about the considerable personal toll exacted by its hero's decision to fight back against the forces of evil while adhering to a code of honor, The Dark Knight expands those weighty themes to city scale.
reviews.author: Keith Phipps

reviews.text: A very good movie that falls short of greatness.
reviews.author: Ethan Alter

reviews.text: Ledger's performance reigns over Nicholson's by taking evil to a new level. If you don't see this in theatres, then you are missing out on one of the biggest and best films in history.
reviews.author: Kevin McCarthy

reviews.text: Dark Knight is epic, frightening, unforgettable, unstoppable, and every inch a classic Batman trial, brought to life with disquieting, mouth-slashing sincerity.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: The Dark Knight succeeds as an action film, character study and metaphor for our own terrorism-obsessed time. Even the hoary device of suggesting a bond between the outcast hero and the outrageous criminal, misused in so many films, makes sense.
reviews.author: Lawrence Toppman

reviews.text: The Godfather of summer movies. Yes, I mean it.
reviews.author: Willie Waffle

reviews.text: For all The Dark Knight's occasionally bombastic excess, it sort of does top them all, and not only in star power and sheer number of things blown up.
reviews.author: Dana Stevens

reviews.text: Under the fun summer blockbuster sheen lives an unnerving, serious, complex and ambitious crime epic about three good men with the courage to stand against evil.
reviews.author: Todd Hertz

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a masterpiece, easily the strongest effort in the history of its genre and one of the best movies of the decade.
reviews.author: Greg Maki

reviews.text: Do not go gently into The Dark Knight. It's an electrifying, thought-provoking meditation on the modern wages of fear. And you haven't danced with the devil by the pale moonlight until Heath Ledger has taken your psyche for a twirl.
reviews.author: Nick Rogers

reviews.text: Whatever the causes, the effects of The Dark Knight are subtle and powerful. It's rejuvenating, it renews the faith.
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: The setting may be Gotham City, but the landscape is that of the unconscious, where archetypes roam unfettered by the restraints of the waking world.
reviews.author: Andrea Chase

reviews.text: Locked in a struggle for Gotham's soul, this Batman and Joker are mesmerizing, unforgettable and, yes, complete.
reviews.author: Kevin Williamson

reviews.text: The Dark Knight should not be remembered as the movie that took Heath Ledger out. Thanks primarily to him, it should be remembered as the movie that propelled fantasy action-thrillers to a higher level.
reviews.author: Larry Ratliff

reviews.text: Nolan has turned this comic book creation into almost Wagnerian opera, the characters going through more twists, turns and crescendos then any I could have ever imagined.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: I'm tired of the early Oscar talk too, but when you're talking the best performance in years, if not decades, it's worth talking about. The whole movie is worth the buzz. Christopher 'Slowly Revealing Myself To Be God' Nolan has done it again.
reviews.author: Gina Carbone

reviews.text: [Ledger's] performance is also the most interesting thing in the film, and when the Joker is absent, The Dark Knight loses most of its energy and dynamism.
reviews.author: Stephen Hunter

reviews.text: This film is not only one of the year's best; it may well end up as the finest of 2008. At the very least, it deserves consideration for Best Picture and Best Director, along with the expected Oscar kudos for Ledger.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: See this one on the biggest screen you can (IMAX, ideally), and experience both the magic of top-notch technical filmmaking and the bittersweet pleasure of watching a young actor, gone too soon, giving a performance that won't be forgotten.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is better than you have heard and as good as you had hoped.
reviews.author: Duane Dudek

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is easily the most entertaining bummer of the summer.
reviews.author: Chris Vognar

reviews.text: Let's face it: If you're any sort of pop-culture or movie freak, you're going to see this flick. And you should, just for Ledger.
reviews.author: Tom Long

reviews.text: Christopher Nolan's second Batman adventure is the rare blockbuster that left me engaged and thoughtful instead of bored and bummed out.
reviews.author: J. R. Jones

reviews.text: It's the standard-bearer for the school of comic-book movies that confuses pompousness with seriousness and popular mechanics for drama.
reviews.author: Michael Sragow

reviews.text: You come away impressed, oppressed, provoked, and beaten down, holding on to Ledger's squirrelly incandescence as a beacon in the darkness.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: A masterpiece of good and evil with Oscar-worthy performances and technical accomplishments that has the potential to impact the genre more than any film since Christopher Reeve put on red tights.
reviews.author: Brian Tallerico

reviews.text: Batman's dilemma in The Dark Knight is how to use his bad press, whether he will embrace it or continue to fight it.
reviews.author: Cynthia Fuchs

reviews.text: The Dark Knight resounds with a throbbing topical undercurrent, its superficially good-versus-evil setup slowly revealed to be a complex examination of the ways in which democracies can, and must, combat zealotry.
reviews.author: Nick Schager

reviews.text: Nolan not only raises the bar for superhero movies, again, but also presses a summer full of comic-book movies under the heel of an impressive bat boot.
reviews.author: Robert Davis

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is grim, loud, ugly, mean and disjointed (four out of five ain't bad!); thus, as an evening of fanboy fodder it's very hard to beat: Call it The Dork Night.
reviews.author: Gregory Weinkauf

reviews.text: Ledger's Joker sports greasy, green-tinged hair and a permanent slouch. It's as if he had bad posture as a kid and things only got worse from there.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: My question is can a third episode -- one lacking the unforgettable, superlative performance of Heath Ledger -- possibly top the magnificence of The Dark Knight? I predict a very interesting Oscars next year.
reviews.author: Diva Velez

reviews.text: flat-out exhilarating, a roller-coaster plunge into the heart of darkness... and a tad exhausting
reviews.author: Sean O'Connell

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a brilliant follow-up to Batman Begins
reviews.author: Rebecca Murray

reviews.text: Nolan has shown a new way to tell a superhero story, and it may turn out to be the only way to tell a story about heroes in this troublingly amoral time.
reviews.author: Katey Rich

reviews.text: I have no idea if Ledger will win the Oscar next year. James Dean didn't. However both men left us, albeit too soon, with performances that will endure forever.
reviews.author: Michael A. Smith

reviews.text: A great work of contemporary cinema and easily the most artistically significant film ever made to ever inspire its own fast-food pizza tie-in.
reviews.author: Peter Sobczynski

reviews.text: The most brilliantly complex, perfectly paced, nerve-jangling, moral-wrangling film ever based on a graphically detailed literary work and, dare I say, one of the most important American films to be made in years.
reviews.author: Erik Childress

reviews.text: Mixing bravura filmmaking with flat clichés in about equal amounts, The Dark Knight is all about dualism. Appropriately, the movie's half-inspired, half-frustrating.
reviews.author: Liam Lacey

reviews.text: Shakespearean but overlong, The Dark Knight is two hours of heady, involving action that devolves into a mind-numbing 32-minute epilogue.
reviews.author: Carrie Rickey

reviews.text: Everything rides on the Joker's formidability as a villain who can carry that kind of weight. In his last role, Ledger makes us believe.
reviews.author: Gary Thompson

reviews.text: Ledger's mesmerizingly damaged agent provocateur is the film's dark heart, a presence so malevolently unpredictable that it remains palpable even when he's not on screen.
reviews.author: Maitland McDonagh

reviews.text: Whatever trepidations Ledger may have had about taking on such an iconic role, he blows past them brilliantly, carrying The Dark Knight along with him.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: [Ledger gives] a fine performance regardless, and I wish the movie around it were more deserving.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: A thought-provoking morality tale about the descent into darkness of a vigilante superhero, an anarchistic and sadistic villain, and an ardent idealist whose dreams are shattered.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: Nihilistic, imaginative and emotionally gratifying, The Dark Knight is in many ways a groundbreaking triumph, and perhaps the best superhero film to date.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: It's jam-packed with flawlessly designed set-pieces and skullduggery, sure, but it's also shrouded in grim portent, overlaid with a filigree of despair, and, for good measure, covered in a patina of dire consequence.
reviews.author: Marc Savlov

reviews.text: As much as this is Ledger's movie, that should not diminish the notable accomplishments of other key cast members.
reviews.author: Claudia Puig

reviews.text: Walking out to your own city's streets afterward, you'll likely have a "Hey, this isn't Gotham!" moment. It's a level of transportation that no cackling, Kool Aid-colored villain could achieve, but it's what every comic book fan truly wants.
reviews.author: Tricia Olszewski

reviews.text: Christopher Nolan wanted to make an action movie that was different from other action movies -- darker, more twisted, more despairing, more bleak -- and he has mostly succeeded in this latest Batman installment. He can thank Ledger for a lot of that.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: A superior sequel, remarkable for its blend of serious themes and crowd-pleasing action, with a performance by Heath Ledger that's a memorable coda to a career cut far too short.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: This is not merely a Batman movie. It is not merely a comic-book movie. It is not merely gripping summer entertainment. It is, with Wall-E, one of the two best mainstream films to be released all year and far and away the most hypnotic chiller.
reviews.author: Amy Biancolli

reviews.text: It's a comic-book movie, but it's also a dark and highly complex drama.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is a good -- not great -- superhero movie that crams as many ideas into its 2 1/2 hours as it can and still be considered a summer action picture.
reviews.author: Robert W. Butler

reviews.text: Among this summer's action films, Dark Knight is easily the best in show.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: Remarkable for it's visionary thematic sprawl... and unforgettable for the individual performance of a single actor.
reviews.author: David Foucher

reviews.text: Squaring off the best-ever Batman and the best-ever Joker would've been enough, but director Nolan sticks them inside an ensemble crime saga that should make Scorsese proud.
reviews.author: Michael Dance

reviews.text: Elevates the genre. Ledger triumphs and I loved the bromance between Wayne/Batman and Harvey Dent. Why Maggie Gyllenhaal?
reviews.author: Victoria Alexander

reviews.text: To see it is to understand that Nolan and his co-writer brother Jonathan saw a chance to go deeper into familiar characters and mythology, a chance to meditate on darker-than-usual themes that have implications for the way we live now.
reviews.author: Kenneth Turan

reviews.text: From its grim palette to its wonderfully eerie score, a departure from what Hollywood has always told us a superhero film should be ... Complex, unsettling, and rewarding.
reviews.author: Brian Juergens

reviews.text: Director Christopher Nolan, who cowrote this dense, dark story with brother Jonathan, has taken the comic book super hero movie onto another plateau...Post 9/11 themes dominate...
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: See The Dark Knight and you're guaranteed an exceptionally dark night at the cinema. You'll also see the finest superhero movie in years -- no joke.
reviews.author: David Edwards

reviews.text: Let it be said that [Ledger's is] such a fearless, fierce, menacing turn that comparisons with Jack Nicholson don't come into it. This is the definitive Joker.
It's one of this year's most haunting cinematic experiences.
reviews.author: Marc Lee

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is ahead of the curve, dense and demanding, an art film on a grand scale. It won't make you smile, but it will make you ponder this mesmerizing experience.
reviews.author: Lee Grant

reviews.text: The generation of consumers who swallow this pessimistic sentiment can't see past the product to its debased morality. Instead, their excitement about The Dark Knight's dread (that teenage thrall with subversion) inspires their fealty to product.
reviews.author: Armond White

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is insurmountable fun.
reviews.author: Rex Reed

reviews.text: I previously have had my own auteurist doubts about Mr. Nolan's work, but after The Dark Knight, I may have to rethink my past reservations about Mr. Nolan's place in the 21st-century cinema.
reviews.author: Andrew Sarris

reviews.text: Nolan has shot The Dark Knight with the utmost confidence, and with a gleefully morbid sense of fun that prevents it from becoming oppressively bleak.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: The Dark Knight packs in at least two films worth of action, suspense, spectacle, horror, and nuanced social commentary. You'll want to see it more than twice.
reviews.author: Cole Smithey

reviews.text: The Oscar talk is no hype.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: The Dark Knight [sounds] like heavy stuff -- and it is. But I should add that Nolan also delivers the kick-ass goods, from an opening bank heist a la Michael Mann to a climactic episode of vehicular mayhem a la William Friedkin.
reviews.author: Scott Foundas

reviews.text: Nolan paints an inky portrait of a city falling apart, and in a movie rife with two-faced masquerading freaks, the Joker is merely the least conflicted of the bunch. Ledger's work is improbably droll, impossibly creepy, meticulously detailed.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: Twisted, tortured, terrifying -- and terrific.
reviews.author: Joe Neumaier

reviews.text: Takes the expectations attached to superhero movies and subverts and reverses them in unexpected ways.
reviews.author: Frank Lovece

reviews.text: Ledger slips into the purple suit as if it were an animal skin for a primal, archetypal dance...Nolan's richly realized adaptation of a modern American mythology fulfills our faith in the material and its interpreters.
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: Iron Man and even more so The Dark Knight move the genre into deeper waters. They realize, as some comic-book readers instinctively do, that these stories touch on deep fears, traumas, fantasies and hopes.
reviews.author: Roger Ebert

reviews.text: Analyzing the successes of such a blistering, genre-defining masterwork (I'm already slipping) is tantamount to judging the contours of Michelangelo's David or evaluating the shading and form of Da Vinci's The Last Supper.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: From the start, it drags us down to the fiery pits of Gotham's anarchic hell and never lets us up for air; it is a bruising, unrelenting slice of sensory overload, a captivating spectacle as likely to dazzle the eyes as fray the nerves.
reviews.author: Rossiter Drake

reviews.text: Freed from the confines of an origin story, director Christopher Nolan lets loose with an intense, challenging, flawed and, yes, dark vision of Gotham under siege, featuring an unforgettable final performance by Heath Ledger as the clown prince of crime.
reviews.author: Joe Lozito

reviews.text: The movie may fall shy of greatness, but that's not for lack of trying.
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: Plodding, puffed-up kitsch mistaking itself for profound psycho noir that the source material won't support.
reviews.author: Jurgen Fauth

reviews.text: It's an action-filled crime drama revolving around a dangerous, demented anarchist. Once again, the Joker's wild!
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: Nolan cements his position as Hollywood's premier purveyor of blockbuster smarts.
reviews.author: Mark Dinning

reviews.text: Visually arresting, with an awards-worthy performance from the late Heath Ledger -- the story bogs down in subplots and subplots to subplots.
reviews.author: Harvey S. Karten

reviews.text: Batman takes a fierce stance in favor of untruth, surveillance and (but?) the American way. Bruce Wayne says, 'Batman has no limits,' and there are two sides to that coin.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: While The Dark Knight has all the visual flair and breathtaking action sequences you'd want in this kind of movie, the screenplay by Nolan and his brother Jonathan Nolan keeps the human element front and center.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: If Dark Knight is a nightmare of particularly modern neuroses, then Batman/Bruce Wayne are a tiny ray of hope upon awakening.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is 152 minutes long but is transfixing and all-enveloping, rather than arduous.
reviews.author: Tim Teeman

reviews.text: It's proof that popcorn entertainments don't have to talk down to their audiences in order to satisfy them. The bar for comic-book film adaptations has been permanently raised.
reviews.author: Rene Rodriguez

reviews.text: Holy hyperbole, Batman! The best superhero movie ever is also the best movie of the year so far.
reviews.author: Matt Pais

reviews.text: THE DARK KNIGHT is a spectacular piece of storytelling. It is as giant a leap forward from BATMAN BEGINS as THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK was to STAR WARS.
reviews.author: Eric Vespe

reviews.text: Nolan has provided movie-goers with the best superhero movie to-date, outclassing previous titles both mediocre and excellent, and giving this franchise its Empire Strikes Back.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: In this, the last performance he completed before his death, Ledger had a maniacal gusto inspired enough to suggest that he might have lived to be as audacious an actor as Marlon Brando, and maybe as great.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: Dark Knight is I suppose the greatest superhero movie ever made, but it's so far beyond the genre that attempting to compare it with likes of Spider-Man, is almost laughable.
reviews.author: Joshua Tyler

reviews.text: There is no other way to put this: The Dark Knight is bloody brilliant and you should go see it!
reviews.author: James O'Ehley

reviews.text: The Dark Knight may be the first movie of its kind to substantively, intellectually address the mythos of comic-book action in something vaguely resembling the real world.
reviews.author: Brent Simon

reviews.text: This movie is too in love with itself to make you love it.
reviews.author: Marshall Fine

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is noisy, jumbled, and sadistic.
reviews.author: David Edelstein

reviews.text: This is a rich, complex, visually thrilling piece of pop entertainment, as strong as any superhero epic we've ever seen.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: This movie is grim and jammed together. The narrative isn't shaped coherently to bring out contrasts and build toward a satisfying climax. The Dark Knight is constant climax; it's always in a frenzy, and it goes on forever.
reviews.author: David Denby

reviews.text: Nolan wants to prove that a superhero movie needn't be disposable, effects-ridden junk food, and you have to admire his ambition.
reviews.author: David Ansen

reviews.text: An epic that will leave you staggering from the theater, stunned by its scope and complexity. It's also, thankfully, a vast improvement over his self-serious origin story, 2005's Batman Begins.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: I loved The Dark Knight... It's unbelievably dark and uncompromised; it's the film noir we deserve for our terrifying 21st century.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: There's a sense of daring in this explosive Batman film, in which we constantly feel on edge, aware of the impending risks and that there is something to lose.
reviews.author: Louise Keller

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is bound to haunt you long after you've told yourself, Aah, it's only a comic-book movie.
reviews.author: Richard Corliss

reviews.text: This is not a Batman movie -- this is a 2008 version of The Untouchables with The Batman as Elliot Ness, The Joker as Al Capone, and much better toys.
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: Daring and uncompromisingly different from previous incarnations of Batman, Nolan hasn't redefined the superhero genre as much as created an unforgettable piece of crime fiction within the context of that realm.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: A dark, ambitious, mature and gritty crime saga the likes of which Michael Mann or Martin Scorsese would be proud to call their own.
reviews.author: Garth Franklin

reviews.text: An ambitious, full-bodied crime epic of gratifying scope and moral complexity, this is seriously brainy pop entertainment that satisfies every expectation raised by its hit predecessor and then some.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: The ideas here are not new to the movie world of cops and criminal, but in the context of a comic book movie, they ring out with startling clarity.
reviews.author: Kirk Honeycutt

reviews.text: The film is quite special but where some films can weather extraneous or padded scenes, The Dark Knight has some distracting bloat to it which keeps it out of masterpiece territory.
reviews.author: Nick Nunziata

reviews.text: The Dark Knight is not only the best film I have seen this year, but quite possibly the best superhero movie ever made.
reviews.author: Brad Miska

reviews.text: Nolan's sequel surpasses the original with an intense, disturbing masterpiece.
reviews.author: Todd Gilchrist

reviews.text: Dark, grim, haunting and inventive, Dark Knight is nothing short of brilliant, representing Chris Nolan's most accomplished and mature work to date and the best and scariest comic-hero adaptation you're likely to see this summer, perhaps the whole year.
reviews.author: Emanuel Levy

reviews.text: The haunting and visionary Dark Knight soars on the wings of untamed imagination.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

synopsis: With the help of allies Lt. Jim Gordon (Gary Oldman) and DA Harvey Dent (Aaron Eckhart), Batman (Christian Bale) has been able to keep a tight lid on crime in Gotham City. But when a vile young criminal calling himself the Joker (Heath Ledger) suddenly throws the town into chaos, the caped Crusader begins to tread a fine line between heroism and vigilantism.
